title: Do difficulty adjustment based on target difficulty instead of achieved difficulty
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->


## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
This PR changes the way the difficulty adjustment works. Currently it uses the achieved difficulty of a block. This means that a really strong block will make it harder for new blocks to be created. 

This is not correct. On every block there is a target difficulty and if that target difficulty is achieved in a shorter or longer than expected time, the target difficulty should be adjusted up or down proportionally to the time difference. 

For example (assuming very short block windows): 
Target difficulty is at 100, block time 60s. A block comes in with achieved difficulty 1,000,000 at 60s. Target difficulty should not change. 
Another block comes in with achieved difficulty 3,000,000, 90s after the first block. The difficulty should actually decrease to between 50-75, because the target was achieved, but in a longer time. 

## Consensus Changes
Note the following consensus changes were made:
1. The previous target difficulty is used when calculating new target difficulty. Nodes using achieved difficulty will be expecting a much higher difficulty
2. The maximum block time is now part of consensus constants. Previously it was set at 6
3. The target difficulty will never be less than the minimum difficulty field in consensus constants. This field always existed, but was only used for setting the initial difficulty. Alternatively we could rename it to initial difficulty, but it is useful to have a method of limiting blocks being created very quickly on an empty block chain with an old genesis block.

title: If tor socket has some kind of error, it shouldn't be read from again
body:
The contract for AsyncRead is generally that if there is an `Some(Err(_))`
or `Some(None)`, `poll_read` should never be called again. This fix
breaks the loop if a socket error is received. The tor controller will
attempt to reconnect on a "fresh" socket.

This prevents infinite looping of this log (confirmed on iOS app):
```
 [comms::tor::control_client] ERROR Line framing error when reading from tor control server: 'Io(Os { code: 57, kind: NotConnected, message: "Socket is not connected"  })'
```

The following is unclear:
1. The reason this happens in the first place (tor crash?)
1. If the connection can be reestablished (maybe tor crashed and
   restarted? If so then reconnect will work)

title: Faster block syncing with basic header validation
body:
## Description
- The block sync logic was updated to be less reliant on syncing headers first allowing only basic header validation(sequence, hash chaining and linking to genesis block) to be performed during the block sync process.
- During block syncing it first attempts to determine if the local chain is on the best network chain. If it is, it can immediately start syncing blocks without first downloading the headers.
When it detects that a fork has occurred, it will attempt to find the split block height by downloading a set of headers from the minimum tip height to the genesis block. This can be done using only a few header bundle requests. Once the split height is determined syncing of blocks can be performed by requesting blocks by height from the split height to the network tip. Requesting blocks using hashes is no longer required as only the sync peers with the specific best chain are used for requesting blocks.
- The number of headers that is requested in a single query was made configurable. 
- Using a single sync peer or randomly requesting blocks from different sync peers that have the best chain was made configurable.

## Motivation and Context
These changes will result in faster syncing as the number of header requests are reduced for forked block syncs and eliminated for lagging block syncs. This approach requires only basic validation to be performed on the synced headers during the block sync process.

## How Has This Been Tested?

hidden service reliability. If the tor control server disconnects, the 
controller will attempt to reconnect every 5 seconds until either

1. Events and response text is split into seperate streams
1. The hidden service is immediately recovered once a connection is

This PR seems to solved the "missing peers" conundrum.

Background: using the async peer manager (blocking threadpool, sync

component would not be able to find that peer. This did not happen when
changing to the sync peer manager. Thanks to @neonknight and

title: Fix for mobile wallet discovery + "memorynet"
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
The DHT did not propagate private discovery messages to wallets because
they do not have the `MESSAGE_PROPAGATION` feature.

This PR changes the behaviour of the DHT to include wallets in
discovery propagation messages. Internally, the Forward step of the DHT pipeline 
has a special case that will propagate discovery messages to wallets. The closest peer selection 
has been adjusted to allow the caller to specify the PeerFeatures of the closest nodes to target by using the `neighbours_with_features` call.
_NOTE:_ because those nodes will not propagate the message further, the selection ensures 
that a minimum number of propagation nodes are always selected   

This PR also includes a new example called "memorynet". `memorynet`, as
the name suggests, is a small in-memory DHT network consisting of a
number of "base nodes" and "wallets" (all that differs is their feature
flags).

The following happens when running `memorynet`:
1. A single "seed node", `NUM_NODES` "base nodes" and `NUM_WALLETS` "wallets" are generated and started.
1. All "base nodes" join the network via the "seed node"
1. All "wallets" join the network via a random "base node"
1. The first "wallet" in the list attempts to discover the last "wallet" in the list
1. The result of the discovery is printed and the network is shut down

The example can be run with this command:
`RUST_LOG=trace cargo run --example memorynet 2> /tmp/debug.log`

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->

This PR provides a full integration test with 2 wallets and a base node and fixes a bug in the output manager that allows for the the wallet to broadcast completed transactions.

* [ ] Feature refactor (No new feature or functional changes, but performance or technical debt improvements)
* [x] New Tests
* [ ] Documentation
